In tuberculous meningitis, steroids are recommended to reduce inflammation of the meninges, which is supported by evidence showing their effectiveness in this context. Similarly, in tuberculous pericarditis, steroids are indicated to manage inflammation of the pericardium, as they can help prevent complications such as heart failure. However, in ileo-caecal tuberculosis, steroids are not typically used as they do not address the localized infection effectively and may worsen the condition. For adrenal involvement, while steroids mimic adrenal hormones, they are not primarily indicated for treating inflammation in adrenal tuberculosis. Therefore, the correct answer is that steroids are not indicated in ileo-caecal tuberculosis.
